How does Verus prevent miners or stakers from attempting to exclude transactions from a block and front-running them, and what incentives are in place to encourage fair behavior?

Verus has implemented several measures to prevent miners or stakers from attempting to exclude transactions from a block and front-running them. One key aspect is the way fees are distributed. Specifically, the last miner or staker to complete a block of an export retroactively receives 10% of all fees from processing that export, including all conversions, once the rollup is processed as an import. This incentivizes fair behavior, as attempting to exclude transactions would not guarantee a profit.

Another important aspect is the ability of import transactions to include up to n/2 arbitrage transactions, where n is the number of reserves in a liquidity basket currency. This allows miners or stakers to earn money by joining transactions and bringing them close to market, without risking loss.

Additionally, the protocol is designed such that if a miner or staker does end up putting more value of transactions in a block that caps the export rollup, they will reliably earn meaningful rewards without risk of loss.

These mechanisms combined serve to disincentivize any miner or staker from attempting to exclude a large set of transactions from a block and front-run all of them, as they would have an even chance of having all of those excluded transactions put back in with their transaction, turning potential gain into potential loss.

Furthermore, the Verus Coin Foundation offers bug bounties to encourage responsible disclosure of any actual protocol bugs, which helps to ensure the security and integrity of the protocol.

Bug Bounties 💰
While we don’t expect it to be easy to find bugs in the protocol, The Verus Coin Foundation is offering a bounty of at least 500 VRSC (possibly more for security related reports) for the first 10 people who are first to report any actual protocol bug before mainnet release, meaning failure of a properly executed command or API on a functioning VRSCTEST or PBaaS chain to function as intended.
If anyone is first to find and describe the exploit for an exploitable security hole in any part of the protocol, the bounty will be a minimum of 1,000 VRSC, and for a serious potential security issue, 10,000 VRSC.
